On a failed save, the character gains a {@table short-term madness|dmg|short-term form of madness}, or a {@table long-term madness|dmg|long-term form} if the save fails by 5 or more, that you choose or determine randomly (see {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).
A deep trench lines the edge of this natural cavern from which green fire belches sporadically. To either side of the doorway are unlit braziers mounted in brackets on the wall.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Guarding the entrance to {@area 40|40} is a {@creature star spawn hulk|mtf}. It attacks characters that attempt to enter {@area 40|40}. If the characters bear a brazier lit with green flame the creature cowers and lets them pass.

entries.name: Trench
entries: A 10-foot-deep trench skirts the perimeter. A creature that enters the trench for the first time on a turn, or starts its turn there, takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage.

Veins of midnight black minerals carve through the rock walls of this huge fane, giving it an unsettlingly visceral look. Two staircases lead up to a raised level above which is a broad fissure open to the ruins above. On this level, four braziers of green flame burn brightly, illuminating a haunting ritual sacrifice about to take place.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Four {@creature cult fanatic|mm|cult fanatics} and two {@creature kraken priest|vgm|kraken priests} are engaged in the ritual. One priest pins down Balama Domine (NG female Turami human {@creature thug}) while the other concentrates on a ritual that transforms Balama into a {@creature star spawn mangler|mtf} at the end of the priest's second turn.
Characters can prevent the ritual by depriving the priests of their sight or ability to speak, breaking the caster's concentration, or casting {@spell counterspell} or {@spell dispel magic}.

entries.name: Trapped Stairs
entries: The stairs closest the door are trapped. Stepping on the top stair causes the staris to tilt, turning into a slide. Simultaneously, a 10-foot square pit filled with green fire opens at the bottom of the stairs. Any creature on the stairs when the trap is triggered must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or slide into the pit.
When a creature enters the pit for the first time on a turn, or starts its turn there, it takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) fire damage.
Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 18 or higher notice the trap, and can avoid the top step.

entries.name: Ceiling & Levels
entries: The ceiling of this chamber is 50 feet tall. The platform is 20 feet tall.

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: The 15-foot-radius hole in the ceiling leads to {@area F|f} in the Ruins of Ascarle.
This wide chamber is bordered by midnight black columns in stoas. In the centre are six identical green stone statues. The hideous forms vomit forth twisting beams of black energy.

entries.name: Statues
entries: Each statue can be rotated using an action. The beams continue until they hit a statue, wall, column, or creature. Overlapping beams has no additional effect.
A creature hit by the beam is targeted by a {@spell ray of enfeeblement} (DC 20). If a beam hits a pillar, a {@spell wall of fire} (DC 20) stretches between each pillar and wall on that side.

If a beam hits a statue it stops there. Different symbols can be made by the beams by rotating the statues. Each symbol causes a different effect (see {@adventure appendix E|CallfromtheDeep|15|Statue Symbols}):

items.name: Symbol A.
items.entry: A {@creature yuan-ti anathema|vgm} is summoned between the central pillars—it attacks randomly.

items.name: Symbol B.
items.entry: Both doors on the eastern wall unlock until the symbol changes.

items.name: Symbol C.
items.entry: Each creature in the room is subjected to the {@spell slow} spell (DC 20) until the symbol changes.

items.name: Symbol D.
items.entry: A {@creature doppelganger} of each creature appears in the room in a mirrored position (as if creating symmetry down the central line).

items.name: Symbol E.
items.entry: Each creature in the room is subjected to the {@spell haste} spell until the symbol changes.

entries.name: Doors
entries: The doors on the eastern wall are both locked, and can only be opened by making the required symbol. Attempting to open the doors before they are unlocked causes the following effects:

items.name: Left-Hand Door.
items.entry: A creature that opens the door sees a cavernous tunnel beyond, created by the {@spell silent image} spell (DC 20). A creature that steps through the door is teleported to {@area 67|67}, though the illusion responds as if they had walked through. Casting {@spell dispel magic} (DC 20) on the door ends both the illusion and teleportation magic.

items.name: Right-Hand Door.
items.entry: A creature that opens the door causes the floor on the corridor beyond to be targetted by a permanent {@spell spike growth} spell (DC 20). It can be removed by {@spell dispel magic} (DC 20).

entries.name: Ceiling & Levels
entries: The chamber is 30 feet tall. The levels by the door are 20 feet high.

entries.name: 42–59 Illithid Lair
entries: Sculpted from burnished star metal and bent glass, the lair of the illithid colony hideously alien. It was constructed by illithid thralls after the great domed caverns were created from the original caves. The inhabitants are the disciples of Zellix'Phor, a handful of newly created mind flayers, and the colony's thralls which serve them without question.

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: Around the rear of the illithid lair is a 15-foot-radius hole which leads to {@area G|g} in the Ruins of Ascarle. The water is held back by arcane runes (see "{@area General Features: Dungeons of Ascarle|gfdoa|x}").

entries.name: Additional Features: Illithid Lair
entries: The following features are common throughout the lair:

entries.name: Ceilings, Floors, and Walls
entries: Each chamber is 10 feet tall. Most surfaces are made of burnished meteoric iron that is iridescent and cold to the touch.

entries.name: Gas Traps
entries: Several areas of the lair are trapped. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher notice pressure plates on the floor.

Stepping on a pressure plate triggers the trap. All doors slam shut and lock as poisonous gas fills the room. Creatures in the room when the trap activates, and when a creature starts its turn in the room, muts make a DC 20 Constitution saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The gas linger for 10 minutes, or until a door is opened.

entries.name: Light
entries: The entire lair is well lit by glowing crystals built into the walls, powered by generators in {@area 45|45}.

entries.name: Qualith Door Locks
entries: Mounted on both sides of the door to this chamber are plates of burnished metal embossed with a braille-like form of tactile writing known as {@language Qualith|vgm}. Mind flayers use their tentacles to read Qualith, which is composed in four-line stanzas indecipherable to other creatures. A creature that touches a Qualith inscription, however, can receive fragmentary insight into the multilayered thoughts contained within it. A non-illithid that wants to understand a Qualith inscription can make a DC 18 Intelligence check to interpret the inscription. A failed attempt results in a crushing headache and requires the creature to succeed on a DC 11 Wisdom saving throw or develop a form of {@table short-term madness|dmg} (see "{@variantrule Madness}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}). A {@spell comprehend languages} spell provides an understanding of the text roughly equivalent to what a mind flayer would get from it.

Each door plate is imbued with psionic energy and functions like an {@spell arcane lock} spell. The Qualith inscription on the plate describes the genuflections a mind flayer must make with its tentacles to open the door. Other creatures with at least four tentacles can imitate these motions to bypass the lock, provided they can interpret the inscription. A creature must be within 5 feet of the door to open it in this way. Creatures without the requisite tentacles and knowledge must deal with the lock by more conventional means, such as a {@spell knock} spell. If magic is unavailable, a locked door can be opened with a successful DC 30 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.
Sprytni poszukiwacze przygód mogą odkryć, że zdekapitowana głowa Pogromcy Umysłów, ożywiona za pomocą zaklęcia {@spell animate dead}, może zostać użyta do uzyskania dostępu do zamków.
Unless held open, doors with Qualith door locks automatically close and lock moments after use.

entries.name: Restoration Pods
entries: Several chambers within the lair contain Restoration Pods. These pods are used to rest by the mind flayers. A creature can use an action to step into a pod and close it. Needles pierce the creature's flesh, pumping restoring fluid into them. The creature must make a Constitution saving throw. The DC equals 10 + the number of times the creature has used a pod in the last 24 hours. On a successful save, the creature gains the benefits of a long rest. On a failed save, the creature gains a level of {@condition exhaustion}. Either way, the process takes 1 minute.

entries.name: Mutations
entries: The mind flayers experiment on their captives, causing mutations which last until the creature is cured by {@spell greater restoration} or similar magic.
When a creature is referred to as a mutant, or a creature suffers a mutation, roll on the following table:

rows: The colour of the target's hair, eyes, and skin become blue, purple, pink, or patterned.
The target's eyes push out of its head at the end of stalks.
The target's hands grow claws, which can be used as {@item dagger|phb|daggers}.
One of the target's legs grows longer than the other, reducing its walking speed by 10 feet
The target's eyes become beacons, filling a 15-foot cone with dim light when they are open.
A pair of leathery wings sprout from the target's back, granting it a flying speed of 30 feet
The target's ears tear free from its head and scurry away; the target is {@condition deafened}.
Two of the target's teeth turn into oversized, blunt tusks.
The target's skin becomes scabby, granting it a +1 bonus to AC but reducing its Charisma by 2 (to a minimum of 1)
The target's arms and legs swap, preventing the target from moving unless it crawls.
The target's arms become tentacles with fingers on the ends, increasing its reach by 5 feet.
The target's legs grow incredibly long and springy, increasing its walking speed by 10 feet.
The target grows a whip-like tail, which it can use as a {@item whip|phb}.
The target's eyes turn black, and it gains {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 120 feet.
The target swells, tripling its weight.
The target becomes skeletal, halving its weight.
The target's head doubles in size.
The target's ears become wings, giving it a flying speed of 5 feet.
The target's body becomes unusually brittle, causing the target to have vulnerability to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.
The target grows another head, causing it to have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, or {@condition stunned}.

entries: The circular chamber before you is formed of featureless, iridescent metal. Circular doors lead farther into the structure.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two mutant {@creature sahuagin baron} thralls guard the chamber. They have the following magic items:

items: Each wears {@item mind carapace plate armor|vgm|mind carapace plate mail} (AC 18).
Each wields a {@item mind blade greatsword|vgm|mind blade: greatsword} ({@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., dealing 14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage on a hit).

entries: If one of the thralls dies, the other heads to the door to area 42a, then through {@area 43|43} into {@area 44|44} where it attempts to sound the alarm (see {@area 44|44}).

entries.name: Trapped Corridor
entries: The corridor marked 42a is trapped with a gas trap (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}"). In addition to the doors locking, a panel slides across the southern wall blocking off the chamber beyond. The panel can be opened like a Qualith door lock (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}").
Metallic pipes wind across the walls of this corridor.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A {@creature mind flayer} is adjusting gauges in the room with two scrag thralls ({@creature troll|mm|trolls} with a 30-ft. swim speed).

entries.name: Pipes
entries: The pipes provide several functions: keeping the air fresh, providing poison for gas traps, fuel for fire sources, and removal of waste fluids from laboratories.

A creature that misses a melee attack roll within 5 feet of the walls must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, hitting and destroying a pipe on a failed save. Pipes might also be destroyed by certain spell effects at the DM's discretion. When a pipe is destroyed, roll a {@dice d6}:

rows: Explosive gas fills the room. Any open flames in the area cause an explosion. Each creature in the area must make a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The flame is then extinguished.
Smoke fills the room. Visibility is reduced to 5 feet until the end of the pipe-breaking creature's next turn.
Poison gas fills the room. Each creature must make a DC 20 Constitution saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
Enervating gas fills the room. All Strength and Dexterity checks made in the room have disadvantage until the end of the pipe-breaking creature's next turn.
Waste lubricant sprays into the room. Each creature must succeed on a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw or fall {@condition prone}.

Mutative gas fills the room. Each creature must succeed on a DC 20 Constitution saving throw or roll on the {@table Mutations table|CallfromtheDeep} (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}").

entries.name: 44. Control Room
entries: The DC for the Qualith door lock on this room is 28. The DC for entering using a Strength check is 35 (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}").
Lining the walls are curved glass panes across which arcane symbols glide. A broad panel of alien matal covered in small indentations protrudes from the lower edge of the planes.

entries.name: Control Panel
entries: The {@language Qualith|vgm} on the control panel can be interpreted in the same way as a Qualith door lock (DC 28). Creatures using the control panel can initiate the following:

items.name: Full Detoxification.
items.entry: On initiative count 20, poison gas fills every room in the illithid lair (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}" but without locking doors) for 10 minutes, then dissipates.

items.name: Mass Unlock.
items.entry: All Qualith door locks in the lair unlock, allowing them to open and close freely.

items.name: Lockdown.
items.entry: All Qualith door locks in the lair swing shut and lock. The DC to open them using a Strength check increases to 35.

items.name: Alarm.
items.entry: A blaring siren echoes throughout the lair. Any mind flayers within converge on this room.

items.name: Jar Check.
items.entry: An outline of the dungeons appears on the glass panel. Intact canopic jars (see "{@area Abjuration Brains|abjuration brains|x}") appear as white dots, destroyed jars as red dots. The effect is akin to a {@spell locate object} spell.

entries: Characters who attempt to use the panel without understanding it set off one {@dice 1d5|random|1d5} effect.
Pistons of strange metal pump alongside whirrling blocks that fill this chamber.

entries.name: Generators
entries: These rooms contain psionic generators that provide power for the lair. They can be destroyed (AC 19, 50 hit points, damage threshold 15, immunity to psychic and poison damage), or deactivated with a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check, followed by a successful DC 20 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}. Destroying or deactivating both generators plunges the lair into darkness and unlocks all Qualith door locks.

If a single generator takes 65 or more damage in a single turn, it explodes. Each creature in a 50-foot radius sphere must make a DC 17 Dexterity saving throw, taking 99 ({@damage 18d10}) force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful save. This damage could cause the second generator to explode. The explosion is powerful enough to destroy the walls of the lair.

If both generators be destroyed simultaneously, a portal to the Astral Plane rips through the fabric of reality. A creature can assume this information by succeeding on a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check while examining the machines. The portal leads to the Fractured Hand on the Astral Plane (see "{@adventure Astral Retreat|CallfromtheDeep|9|Astral Retreat}").
The rear of this room is taken up by a metal workbench covered with unrecognisable tools and machinery. Atop the desk is a spider-like construct of iridescent black metal.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The construct on the desk is a {@creature retriever|mtf} that was forgotten by the drow. Luzgrigaul found the construct and repaired it, adapting it to obey only their commands.
If the characters have already encountered Luzgrigaul, the retriever is no longer here. It is tracking the characters.

Bright light streams from white crystals onto cubes of transluscent, purple force. Trapped within the cubes are horrendously mutated, pitiful creatures. A small metal panel with braille-like markings on it juts out from the wall.

entries.name: Cells
entries: There are four 7-foot cubes created by a psionic {@spell wall of force} effect. The cells can be 'opened' and 'closed' individually using the control panel, which can be understood like a Qualith door lock (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}").

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Each prison cell contains a mutated creature:

items: A skeletal triton {@creature veteran} named {@creature Vlaryn Vuuxariath|CallfromtheDeep}. Her equipment has been destroyed. She was a member of the Fort Vuuxariath militia but was captured by sea spawn while on duty and brought here. The mind flayers have repeatedly experimented on her, reducing her weight as low as possible while keeping her alive. She accompanies her rescuers and can fight if given a weapon.

A triton {@creature veteran} named {@creature Otanyn Vuuxariath|CallfromtheDeep} who has prouted horns all over her body. She was kidnapped in the same manner as Vlaryn. Otanyn can make slam attacks ({@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target, dealing 6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage on a hit. Otanyn knows the mind flayers kidnapped a triton spellcaster at the same time as her. The spellcaster was killed, and their brain stored in a strange jar before being moved elsewhere in the dungeon (see "{@area Abjuration Brains|abjuration brains}").

A {@creature mutated merrow|CallfromtheDeep|merrow} with enormous pincers and frenzied eyes. It has been mutated by the mind flayers in their attempts to create more powerful bodyguards. Its claw attacks deal 13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) daamge and grapple the target (escape DC 14).

The final cell contains a humanoid mutated beyond recognition. Its eyes extend from tis head on stalks, its neck has been turned into a tentacle, its arms and legs have been replaced with insectoid limbs, and its mouth turned into a beak. The poor creature can barely move. Any who look upon it must succeed on a DC 20 Charsima saving throw. On a failed save, the creature gains a {@table short-term madness|dmg|short-term form of madness}, or a {@table long-term madness|dmg|long-term form} if the save fails by 5 or more, that you choose or determine randomy (see {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon master's Guide}).

entries: A hole in the ceiling allows access to the level above.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: This chamber is guarded by a mutant dire scrag thrall ({@creature dire troll|mtf} with a 30 ft. swim speed).

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: This room provides access to {@area 88|88} via a hole in the ceiling.
Strapped to something resembling a glass throne is a humanoid corpse whose insides are mostly outside. A robed figure is carefully dissecting the exposed organs.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A single {@creature mind flayer} performs the autopsy, part of the research initiated by Thiliossk to further understand native humanoids. It uses its mind blast then flees the chamber—looking for thralls to guard it.
Gobs of grey mold grow on shelves extending from the walls.

entries.name: Mold
entries: Sour-smelling mold fed to mind flayer captives grows on the shelves. There are twenty rations in total.
Vents line the walls of this triangular corridor.

entries.name: Gas Trap
entries: There are three pressure plates linked to a gas trap in this room (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}").
A hole in the ceiling allows access to the level above.

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: This room provides access to {@area 80|80} via a hole in the ceiling.
A strange suit of armour, the size of an ogre, stands against the chamber wall. Opposite the armour is a tool bench and beyond that a glass pod. Lining the walls are smaller pods.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: {@creature Luzgrigaul|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) is working on the {@item psionic suit|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}). If intruders enter, Luzgrigaul enters the suit usign an action, and psychically calls the {@creature retriever|mtf} from {@area 46|46} to assist. It arrives in 4 rounds.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The {@item psionic suit|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}) can be taken if Luzgrigaul dies. The wall pods contain a {@item survival mantle|vgm}, a {@item mind blade longsword|vgm} to which any creature can attune, a {@item shield of far sight|vgm}, a {@item ring of spell storing} containing the {@spell plane shift} spell, and a {@item wand of lightning bolts}.

entries.name: Restoration Pod
entries: There is a single pod in this chamber (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}").
Platforms topped with thin mattresses jut out from the walls of this chamber. Stacked in a recess are a dozen leather parcels.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two Rocklander {@creature commoner} thralls and three {@creature sahuagin raider|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) thralls rest on the beds. They attack any intruders.

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: This room provides access to {@area 83|83} via a hole in the ceiling.

entries.name: Parcels
entries: The parcels contain a ration of grey mold each.
This small antechamber is decorated with an arrangement of severed hands. A great diversity of morphology is on show, from humanoid hands to crustacean claws.

entries.name: Trap
entries: The trap functions as a gas trap but injects mutative gas. On a failed save, a creature gains a mutation (see gas traps and mutations—{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}).
Stepped platforms of cut stone are stacked on either side of this chamber. The floor is peppered with blackened, inch-wide holes, and scratch marks cover the walls.

entries.name: Floor
entries: The floor is sunk 25 feet. The area is 35 feet tall.

entries.name: Platforms
entries: The platforms vary in height (see map) but all have sheer faces. Climbing a platform is impossible without climbing gear. Even with the correct gear, it requires a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: Combat Training
entries: {@i Complex trap (level 11–16, dangerous threat)}

This combat training facility was designed by Luzgrigaul. The facility pitches the trainee against animated constructs, whilst making them dodge jets of flame erupting from the floor and spinning blades which scythe the room.

entries.name: Trigger
entries: The chamber door locks behind anyone who enters. Unless immediately opened, the trap activates.

entries.name: Initaitive
entries: The trap acts on initiative count 20, 10, and 5.

entries.name: Active Elements
entries: Combat Training involves construct combatants, jets of flame, and scything blades.

items.name: Counter Combatants (Initiative 20).
entries: Five {@creature combat training construct|CallfromtheDeep|constructs} emerge from the secret trap door and attack the creature with the highest Intelligence. They use {@creature helmed horror} statistics with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: They are immune to fire damage, and the following spells: {@spell cone of cold}, {@spell ice storm}, {@spell lightning bolt}.
Their longsword attacks deal an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage, and they can {@action shove} a creature within 5 feet of them as a bonus action.

items.name: Flame Jets (Initiative 10).
items.entry: Fire shoots from the holes in the floor. Each creature standing on the floor takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage.

items.name: Scything Blades (Initiative 5).
items.entry: Psionically charged blades swarm toward non-construct creatures in the room. Each non-construct creature must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) slashing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful save.

entries.name: Dynamic Elements
entries: The flame jets become more dangerous the longer the trap remains active.

items.name: Added Fuel.
items.entry: The damage from the Flame Jets element increases by 11 ({@damage 2d10}) each round after it activates, to a maximum of 55 ({@damage 10d10}).

entries.name: Constant Elements
entries: A creature that starts its turn on the floor must make a {@footnote saving throw|No information about the ability or DC is provided. I recommend a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw.} against the Flame Jets.

entries.name: Countermeasures
entries: There are a few ways the trap can be overcome:

items.name: Open the Door.
items.entry: The door is locked with a Qualith door lock (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}"). Any creature that leaves the room is no longer affected by the trap. If all creatures leave the room, the trap resets.

items.name: Plug the Jets.
items.entry: A creature can use an action to plug a 5-foot square of holes from which the flame jets burst with a non-flammable material, such as cloth soaked in water. The flame jets no longer function in that area.

items.name: Dispel the Blades.
items.entry: The swarming blades are powered by psionics. A creature can {@action ready} an action to cast {@spell dispel magic} (DC 15) on the blades as they swarm. Doing so reduces the DC to avoid the blades by 3. When the DC drops to 0, the blades deactivate.

items.name: Kill the Constructs.
items.entry: Killing all five helmed horrors causes the trap to deactivate.

entries.name: 57. Corridor of the Conjured

entries: The walls of this corridor ripple with turquoise light as if illuminated through water. At one end is a recess in the wall which contains a humanoid head and glass panel.
Gdy wejdą bohaterowie, przeczytaj lub sparafrazuj poniższą wypowiedź:

Two softly glowing turquoise figures appear before you. Noiselessly, they engage in skilled melee combat with each other. One of the figures is a tentacled mind flayer, sporting an ornate glove. The other is a githyanki knight wielding a silver greatsword.
Eventually, the mind flayer parries the knight's greatsword and uses the momentum to spin behind them. As its tentacles wrap around the skull of the silently screaming creature, the figures dissolve.

entries.name: Holograms
entries: The recess in the wall contains a plate and panel. If a creature's head or brain is placed atop the plate, the panel can be used to psionically access its memories akin to a {@spell speak with dead} spell. The panel can be understood like a Qualith door lock (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}"). Tharcereli uses this to relive past battles—the current head is that of Gyx, a githyanki knight.
Dozens of decapitated heads stare out unseeingly from the walls. They vary from humanoid to alien beings. Save the morbid decoration, there is little of note in this chamber.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: {@creature Tharcereli|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) is in this chamber communing with the still-living brains of their foes. They are accompanied by two {@creature lizard king}/{@creature lizard queen|mm|queen} thralls.

entries.name: Heads
entries: The heads belong to Tharcereli's vanquished foes. A creature that sees the morbid display for the first time muts make a DC 10 Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the character gains a {@table short-term madness|dmg|short-term form of madness}, or a {@table long-term madness|dmg|long-term form} if the save fails by 5 or more, that you choose or determine randomly (see {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Restoration Pod
entries: This room contains one pod (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}").
Bulbous glass pods bubble from the burnished metal walls of this room. Within are spectacular weapons of myriad design.

entries.name: Storage Pods
entries: Each of the four pods contains a weapon that belonged to one of Tharcereli's victims:

items: A {@item tallyn amberheart's flame tongue longsword|CallfromtheDeep|flame tongue longsword} which belonged to a Tallyn Amberheart—a human paladin of The Red Knight. Those who wield it hear a commanding woman's voice in their mind instructing during combat. Once per long rest, a creature attuned to the blade can use a bonus action to cause an ally within 30 feet of them that can hear them to use their reaction to make a melee weapon attack.

A {@item werydd giantsbane's giant slayer greataxe|CallfromtheDeep|giant slayer greataxe} which belonged to Werydd Giantsbane—a shield dwarf champion. A creature attuned to the weapon grows ginger braids and swells in girth. They also gain advantage on saving throws against poison, and resistance to poison damage.

A {@item captain tharhava shestendeliath's scimitar of speed|CallfromtheDeep|scimitar of speed} that belonged to Captain Tharhava Shestendeliath—a non-binary blue dragonborn swashbuckler. A creature attuned to the weapon becomes obsessively driven by the draconian voice in their mind commanding them to avenge their death at the hands of Tharcereli. The creature cannot unattune to the weapon, and are unwillig to part with it until Tharcereli is killed. In addition, they gain the breath weapon of a blue {@race dragonborn} (see chapter 2 of the {@i Player's Handbook}).

A {@item baragsh's +3 adamantine glaive|CallfromtheDeep} whose green blade is banded and mottled in a pattern reminiscent of astral skies. It belonged to Baragsh—a male orc captain of a spacefaring vessel from the Astral Plane. A creature attuned to the weapon gains proficiency in vehicles (air), and can add their proficiency bonus to checks made to navigate in the Astral Plane.

entries.name: 60–70 Elder Brain Chambers
entries: The chambers of Zellix'Phor are domes of crystal and alien metal. They look entirely out of place in the artificially demolished cavern as they have been ripped straight from the crashed nautiloid. Within, the chambers of Zellix'Phor are well maintained. They include processing rooms for new thralls, storage chambers for important items, and the resting pool of the elder brain itself.

entries.name: Additional Features: Elder Brain Chambers
entries: The following features are common throughout the elder brain chambers:

entries.name: Ceilings, Floors, and Walls
entries: Each perimeter dome is 20 feet tall. Central areas are 10 feet tall. Most surfaces are made of burnished star metal that is cold to the touch.

entries.name: Light
entries: The entire lair is well lit by glowing crystals built itno the walls, powered by the psionic force of Zellix'Phor.

entries.name: Qualith Door Locks
entries: See "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}".

entries.name: Secret Doors
entries: There are numerous secret doors throughout the chambers. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 20 or higher notice these circular doors. The doors otherwise function as Qualith door locks (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}").

entries.name: Walkway
entries: A 10-foot-high walkway loops through the permieter domes. A creatrue without a climb speed can pull itself onto the walkway from below as part of its movement with a successful DC 10 Strength check.
A curved, iridescent metal ceiling covered in indecipherable inscriptions makes this chamber feel claustrophobic. A glass plint rises from the centre of the room.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A {@creature brain golem|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) and two {@creature sahuagin baron} thralls, each equipped with a {@item mind blade greatsword|vgm} instead of a {@item trident|phb}, guard this chamber.

entries.name: Communicator
entries: The plinth can be used to initiate a psionic, holographic connection between the user and {@area 70|70}. The user is surrounded by an illusion of the chamber and can communicate telepathically with any creature inside. It can be used like a Qualith door lock (see "{@area Additional Features: Elder Brain Chambers|afebc|x}").
The stained metal floor of this chamber slopes down to a drain, above which floats an edged metal tray. Glass pods on the walls contain gruesome medical implements.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature mind flayer|mm|mind flayers} are dissecting the corpse of a merfolk on the metal tray. They are distracted, reducing their passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score to 11.

entries.name: Furniture
entries: The metal tray is under the effect of a {@spell levitate} spell cast by one of the mind flayers. The glass storage pods contain medical tools equivalent to a {@item healer's kit|phb}.

entries.name: Secret Doors
entries: Hidden behind the doors (see "{@area Additional Features: Elder Brain Chambers|afebc|x}") are ogan libraries where viscera of interest are stored in canopic jars.
Warm, humid air clings and fogs this domed chamber. Pipes running up the walls sporadically puff clouds of acrid smelling effluvia into the air.

entries.name: Secret Doors
entries: The doors (see "{@area Additional Features: Elder Brain Chambers|afebc|x}") allow newly captured victims to be brought into room without using the central walkway.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: When characters enter, a {@creature mind flayer} leading a {@condition stunned} {@creature aldani (lobsterfolk)|toa|aldani} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) enters through the northern secret door. The aldani's name is Klak. They hail from Fort Vuuxaria and accompany the party if rescued.
Foul-smelling fluids splatter the sloping floor of this dome. Chunks of fleshy substance have gathered around the depressed drain in its centre. Along the dome's edge are frosted glass doors.

entries.name: Secret Doors
entries: The doors (see "{@area Additional Features: Elder Brain Chambers|afebc|x}") allow passage into and out of this room.

entries.name: Glass Doors
entries: The glass doors can be operated like Qualith door locks (see "{@area Additional Features: Elder Brain Chambers|afebc|x}") but have two commands. One to become transparent, revealing their contents, and one to open.

Five of the seven chambers are empty. One contains a twisted, mutated corpse that bears little resemblance to anything save a butcher's offal pile. Each character who sees the corpse must make a DC 20 Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the character gains a {@table short-term madness|dmg|short-term form of madness}, or a {@table long-term madness|dmg|long-term form} if the save fails by 5 or more, that you choose or determine randomly (see {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).
The second filled cell contains a {@creature sahuagin-illithid hybrid|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) which attacks madly if released.
Glyphs and sigils arranged in patterns of unnatural geometry dot the metal surfaces of this chamber.

entries.name: Planar Portal
entries: A character who succeeds on a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check understands the glyphs can be used to teleport. If the check succeeds by 10 or more, they learn the movements and words necessary to activate it, which takes an action. When activated, a gate spell appears in the centre of the dome, linked to the Fractured Hand on the Astral Plane (see "{@adventure Astral Retreat|CallfromtheDeep|9|Astral Retreat}").

A failed attempt results in hallucinations of hideous cityscapes of unnatural structures whose angles are wrong, and requires the creature to succeed on a DC 20 Wisdom saving throw or develop a form of {@table short-term madness} (see "{@variantrule Madness|dmg}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: 65. Item Storage
entries: This room is hidden behind a secret door (see "{@area Additional Features: Elder Brain Chambers|afebc|x}"). When characters enter, read or paraphrase the following:
Bulbous glass pods in this cramped chamber contain dozens of strange items.

entries.name: Pods
entries: The pods contain a variety of worthless trinkets.

Tattered sheets of skin, hunks of twitching muscle, and bones reinforced with burnished metal are stored in barrels throughout the room. Standing half-formed in the centre of the dome is a hulking humanoid creation.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Although incomplete, the {@creature flesh golem} is functional and attacks any non-illithid.

A nearby sealed barrel contains ten {@creature crawling claw|mm|crawling claws}. If the golem detects multiple foes, it uses one of its attacks to throw the barrel at the central enemy ({@hit 4} to hit, range 15/30 ft., one target, dealing 15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage on a hit). Whether or not the attack hits the barrel bursts open unleashing the claws, which immediately attack the closest creature other than the golem.

entries.name: Pods
entries: The pods on the back wall contain saws, {@item hammer|phb|hammers}, and other equipment, as well as a {@item manual of flesh golems}.

entries.name: 67. Teleportation Station

entries: Pulsing lights of myriad colours create a circle on the floor of this dome. A glass panel hangs on one of the walls.
The teleportation traps in {@area 41|41} and {@area 73|73|x} lead here.

entries.name: Teleporter
entries: The teleporter can be used to transport up to 8 creatures to {@area 80|80}. It can be understood like a Qualith door lock (see "{@area Additional Features: Elder Brain Chambers|afebc|x}").
Stacked on shelves here are dozens of jars whose designs vary from mesmerising geometrics to hideous tentacles.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature brain golem|CallfromtheDeep|brain golems} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) guard the chamber. Behind a secret door is a {@creature mind flayer} that emerges if it hears combat. It is working on a preservation jar for extended spellcasting using the missing pages from the book in {@area 19|19} as a guide.

entries.name: Jars
entries: The jars each contain a brain, kept alive by preservative fluid.

entries.name: Secret Doors
entries: Behind the doors (see "{@area Additional Features: Elder Brain Chambers|afebc|x}") are brain libraries containing brains kept in standardised metal and glass jars.
Half of this chamber is taken up by a circular pool filled with briny water, the smell of which permeates throughout. Squirming around in the pools are scores of tiny tadpoles.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Each pool is guarded by a triton {@creature gladiator} thrall that doesn't leave the room. Any creature that falls into a pool is beset by mind flayer tadpoles which could, at the DM's discretion, initiate ceremorphosis.

In the centre of the chamber is a broad pool filled with effervescing purple fluid, covered by a glass dome. The walls are made of an oozing metal-stone hybrid and lead to a circular hole in the ceiling giving access to the cavern above.

entries.name: Pool
entries: The glass protecting has AC 20, 50 hit points, and immunity to nonmagical damage. The glass allows telepathy and psychic damage to pass through, otherwise serving as total cover. The fluid restores 10 hit points to any creature submerged in it on initiative 20 each round. A creature in the pool can use it as a communicator (see {@area 60|60}).

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Zellix'Phor the {@creature elder brain|vgm} may have teleported into the pool to escape or ambush the characters. Two {@creature brain golem|CallfromtheDeep|brain golems} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) guard the chamber at all times accompanied by {@creature Druskis|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}).

entries.name: Divination
entries: Zellix'Phor has a permanent {@spell arcane eye} in this chamber. If it detects intruders, the elder brain comes to attack itself or sends minions from surrounding areas.

entries.name: 71–79 Vestress' Tomb
entries: Beneath the desecrated catacombs is a tomb which once belonged to the current Regent of Ascarle, Shava the Damned. Since Shava's reanimation in service of Slarkrethel, the city's previous Regent, an illithid named Vestress, has been interred in the empty tomb. The tomb is protected by Shava and her Krakenar agents, but still shows evidence of its elven history. Vestress is loyal to Slarkrethel, not Zellix'Phor, and could therefore serve as an ally to the characters.

entries.name: Additional Features: Vestress' Tomb
entries: The following features are common throughout Vestress' tomb:

entries.name: Ceilings, Floors, and Walls
entries: Surfaces in this area are made of algae-covered stone. Ceilings are 10 feet high.

entries.name: Light
entries: The tomb is unlit. Creatures within rely on their {@sense darkvision} to see.
On the far wall is a bas-relief half-covered with a mat of algae and seaweed. It depicts an elven ceremony.

entries.name: Bas-Relief
entries: Elven characters instantly recognise the depicted ceremony as a burial.

A thick kelp forest has overgrown this entire chamber, masking signs of its previous use. Floating amongst the wafting brown vegetation are three bloated gellyfish, veined with electric blue striations.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The three giant jellyfish attack any edible prey that enters (use {@creature carrion crawler} statistics with a 30-foot swim speed). The jellyfish maneouver using a bubble beneath their fleshy bodies.
A creature that succeeds on a DC 16 Dexterity ({@skill Medicine}) check within one round of a jellyfish dying can gather {@dice 1d4} minutes of breathable air from the corpse in a container.
A cavernous tunnel extends up ahead.

entries.name: Trap
entries: Any creature that opens the door sees an illusion of a cavernous tunnel created by a {@spell silent image} spell (DC 20). A creature that steps through is teleported to {@area 67|67}, though the illusion responds as if they had walked through.

Four statues of elven figures guard this chamber. Each has the putrefying corpse of an octopus nailed to its chest. Arching over the centre of the room is a stone walkway sculpted with beautiful oceanic reliefs.

entries.name: Ceiling & Walkway
entries: This chamber is 20 feet high. The walkway is 10 feet high.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature merfolk gladiator|CallfromtheDeep|merfolk gladiators} and one {@creature merfolk necromancer|CallfromtheDeep} guard this chamber.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher notice a hiddendoor built into the wall. Characters who succeed on a DC 25 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check discover that pressing a crescent moon on the back of a naerby statue opens the door.

entries.name: 75. Hidden Corridor

entries: A sombre elven elegy can be heard thorughout this corridor.
Secret doors hide this empty corridor (see {@area 74|74} and {@area 76|76|x}).

Woven tapestries cover the walls, floor, and ceiling of this chamber. The unnatural patterns in the fabric are terrible to behold, sending waves of nausea through you. The sheets have been thrown over the furniture, covering everything.

entries.name: Tapestries
entries: If a creature that can see the tapestries starts its turn within 60 feet of them, they must succeed on a DC 20 Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. A creature that succeeds on the saving throw is immune to the tapestries' aura for the next 24 hours.

A creature can close its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If the creature does so, it is effectively {@condition blinded} until the start of its next turn. If the creature looks at the tapestries in the meantime, it must immediately make the save.

entries.name: Altar & Statue
entries: Hidden beneat the fabric are a defiled altar and statue. The statue was of a unicorn but has been decapitated. The altar is covered with six amulets of star metal (500 gp each) and an {@item instrument of the bards, canaith mandolin} that emits dim light on moonless nights.

entries.name: Concealed Door
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 30 or higher notice a door concealed by the tapestry behind the altar. The door is unlocked.
A long corridor stretches out ahead, part of which is elevated on an archway, the rest cut into the rock.

entries.name: Kraken's Maw
entries: {@i Complex trap (level 11–16, dangerous threat)}
This trap was constructed to prevent tomb robbers infiltrating the resting place of Vestress. It is a corridor that fills with surging water, black ink, and crushing teeth.

entries.name: Trigger
entries: This trap activates as soon as a non-Krakenar enters the marked area, and it remains active while any non-Krakenar creature is within the area.

entries.name: Initiative
entries: The trap acts on initiative count 20 and 10.

entries.name: Active Elements
entries: The Kraken's Maw includes a torrent of water and black ink throughout, plus smashing teeth in the central 20 feet.

items.name: Surging Water (Initiative 20).
items.entry: Water surges from north to south. Each creature in the hallway must make a DC 20 Strength saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage, is knocked {@condition prone}, and pushed 30 feet south. On a successful save, the creature takes half the damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone} or shoved. The surging water is difficult terrain.

items.name: Ink Cloud (Initiative 20).
items.entry: The area between the two triggers is filled with a cloud of ink. The area is heavily obscured as long as the trap remains active.

items.name: Crushing Teeth (Initiative 10).
items.entry: Each creature in the central 20 feet of the corridor must make a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw, taking 33 ({@damage 6d10}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Constant Elements
entries: Certain elements affect each creature that ends its turn in an area affected by them.

items.name: Surging Water.
items.entry: Any creature that ends its turn in the corridor must make a saving throw against the Surging Water effect.

items.name: Crushing Teeth.
items.entry: Any creature that ends its turn in the area affected by the Crushing Teeth must make a saving throw against its effect.

entries.name: Countermeasures
entries: Each of the trap's active elements can be thwarted by particular countermeasures.

items.name: Open the Doors.
items.entry: To deactivate the trap, the doors to {@area 78|78} must be opened. To open the doors, a character must first succeed on a DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to find the lock. A successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check disables the sphere of force surroudning the lock ({@spell dispel magic} also works). Success on a DC 20 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb} picks the lock. Finally, a successful DC 20 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check pushes the door open. Each check requires an action.

items.name: Ink Cloud.
items.entry: The ink can be disabled by blocking its flow. A successful DC 20 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}, or a DC 15 Strength check to block up the holes with a cloak of similar object, clears the ink in a 10-foot square.

items.name: Crushing Teeth.
items.entry: A successful DC 20 Strength check allows a character to prevent a set of the teeth activating provided they remain within 5 feet of them. Placing a {@item piton|phb} or similar item to prevent a set of teeth activating requires a successful DC 20 Intelligence check.

entries.name: 78. Tomb of Vestress
entries: The door to this chamber is locked (see {@area 77|77}).

Ahead is a large, vaulted tomb. The place stinks of damp seaweed, and the air feels cold and wet on your skin. At one end of the tomb is a raised dais, upon which lies a stone sarcophagus. At the other end is an enormous tapestry that is an absolute masterpiece.

entries.name: Tapestry
entries: The tapestry serves as a {@item mirror of life trapping}. Viewing it indirectly gives the appearance of an elven masterpiece, depicting sea elves and moon elves gathering on a moonlit, sandy beach. The tapestry has been activated by Vestress, and creatures trapped by it appear as characers woven into the fabric.
The tapestry contains the following individuals:

items.name: Cell 1.
items.entry: Kaznal Jhalass (NE male {@creature drow house captain|mtf} thrall). Kaznal is a long-time thrall of Vestress, whose military knowledge served her well throughout her reign as Regent of Ascarle. Kaznal unthinkingly obeys Vestress' orders but has enough intelligence remaining to make tactical decisions on his own.

items.name: Cell 2.
items.entry: Thûn (CN female {@creature quaggoth thonot}). Thûn was Vestress's favourite 'pet'. She has {@item flensing claws (medium)|vgm|flensing claws} ({@damage 1d10+3|1d10|Flensing Claws}) and a {@item survival mantle|vgm} which allowed her to travel throughout Ascarle when Vestress reigned. Although she was loyal to the old Regent, decades of isolation in the tapestry has driven Thûn insane. She relentlessly attacks anything she sees if released. Her madness can be cured with a {@spell greater restoration} spell, or suppressed with a {@spell calm emotions} spell.

items.name: Cell 3.
items.entry: Meriele Oth'Ereath (NG female sea elf {@creature priest} of {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|MTF}). Meriele is a captive of Vestress who once inhabited Ascarle. She is a devout worshipper of Deep Sashelas who happily assists any who release her and wish to remove the stain of evil from Ascarle. The passage of time since she was imprisoned in the tapestry (over a century) has clouded her mind and although her heart is in the right place, she finds it hard to process new information and stick to plans.

items.name: Cell 4.
items.entry: Aer'Evan Sylvaranth (NG male sea elf {@creature bard|vgm}). Aer'Evan was captured by Vestress so that he might play while she sewed.  She treated her musician well as his virtuoso performances inspired the illithid to create masterpiece tapestries. Despite his good treatment, Aer'Evan is terrified of Vestress who he witnessed devour the brains of his elven kin. If released, he tries to flee from Ascarle but assists any who offer to help him get away safely.

items.name: Cell 5.
items.entry: Mug ({@creature froghemoth|vgm}). Mug was captured by Vestress as a challenge to herself to prove she could weave a creature that would be complex to embroider. She succeeded and has never since released Mug. If released, Mug attacks wildly and randomly.

entries.name: Sarcophagus
entries: The ornate, elven sarcophagus was built for Shava, and portrays scenes of her in life ruling over old Ascarle. However, the illithids have altered the coffin to better represent their outlook, adding burnished plates with funerary rites in {@language Qualith|vgm}, and mind-bending etchings of brains and geometric motifs.

Opening the sarcophagus requires a successful DC 15 Strength check. It contains the body of Vestress, a mind flayer turned {@creature alhoon|vgm} who was once Regent of Ascarle. If characters disturb the sarcophagus, including removing the canopic jar (see below), Vestress animates and attacks. Her sole goal is to defend the canopic jar. She can use the tapestry (see above) to bring forth her preserved minions.

If the jar is destroyed before her, Vestress collapses. She had been mind-altered by Zellix'Phor to defend the jar, but her true master is Slarkrethel. If the characters explain that they are here to kill the elder brain, not the kraken, she can serve as an ally. She can also reveal that there are three more canopic jars hidden throughout the dungeon.

entries.name: Canopic Jar
entries: Built into the sarcophagus is a canopic jar containing a spellcaster's brain concentrating on the {@spell mind blank} spell (see "{@area Abjuration Brains|abjuration brains|x}"). The jar can be removed by prising it out with any edged tool, such as a {@item dagger|phb}. Doing so causes Vestress to rise (see above).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Vestress wears five amethyst rings (250 gp each) and a silver circlet (1,500 gp). The three alcoves on the western wall each contain a masterpiece tapestry woven by Vestress (1,500 gp each).

entries.name: 79. Forum

entries: Tiered seating surrounds a small pit in this circular room. Many of its original features have faded or been destroyed.
This chamber was once used by the elves of Ascarle as a meeting place to discuss ideas, or view an intimate musical or theatrical performance. The area is now empty.

entries.name: 80–89 Illithid Lair Second Level
entries: This area of the dungeon is the second level of the illithid lair. It is similar in all ways to the first level below it.

entries.name: Additional Features: Illithid Lair Second Level
entries: The common features of this area of the dugneon canb e found in "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}".
The iridescent floor of this chamber is etched with sigils and stanzas in Qualith, as is a glass panel on the southern wall. A large hole in the floor provides access to the level below.

entries.name: Teleporter
entries: The panel operates as a Qualith door lock (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}"). Successfully operating it transports up to 8 creatures to {@area 67|67}.

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: This area provides access to {@area 52|52} via a hole in the floor.

entries.name: 81. Mutant Pens
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 16 or higher can hear groaning within this chamber from adjacent areas. When characters enter, read or paraphrase the following:
Three large cages house a panoply of disturbingly mutated monsters. They grope desperately at the bars of their cages with malformed digits.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The room contains five {@filter mutants|bestiary|source=CallfromtheDeep|search=mutant} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) created by Thiliossk, two in each of the southern cells, one in the northern.

A creature that enters the room without first succeeding on a DC 12 Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check is noticed by the mutants, who fly into a rage. Roll initiative for the mutants. On each of their turns, they use an action to make a DC 20 Strength check against the bars of their cage, breaking free on a success. Once escaped, the mutants attack the closest non-mutant until dead, before moving on to the next.

entries.name: Cages
entries: The cages are formed from bars of alien metal akin to iron. The locks on the doors are Qualith door locks (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}"). The bars can be bent or broken with a successful DC 20 Strength check, allowing Large or smaller creatures to pass through.
Thin spiralling shelves line the walls of this chamber. Scuttling along them are hundreds of rats, their brains glowing with dull blue light. A throne sits in the centre.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Three {@creature swarm of cranium rats|vgm|swarms of cranium rats} run along the shelves, which offer half cover to the Tiny beasts. The rats only attack in retaliation.

entries.name: Throne
entries: A creature that sits in the throne while the rats are alive enters a trance. The rats' psionic energy sends their brain into an altered state of existence, allowing them to move around through a virtual version of the lair as if they were there. A character can end the trance as an action.
A hole in the floor allows access to the level below.

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: This room provides access to {@area 54|54} via a hole in the floor.
Floor-to-ceiling tanks of sepia fluid block line of sight through this room. Inside the tanks are mutate dhumanoid forms stripped back to their muscular and skeletal system.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: {@creature Thiliossk|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) is taking notes about a mutated corpse with a {@creature mind flayer} assistant. A {@filter mutant|bestiary|source=CallfromtheDeep|search=mutant} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) holds a tray of implements. Thiliossk would rather capture than kill the characters.

entries.name: Tank
entries: Tanks provide three-quarters cover to Medium creatures and block line of sight.

entries.name: Restoration Pod
entries: There is a single pod in this chamber (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}").
Lights along the walls subtly shift colour and intensity in an almost hypnotic fashion. Standing throughout the room are six glass and metal pods connected to the ceiling via tubes.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature mind flayer|mm|mind flayers} are using the pods. Loud noises or disturbances to the pods cause them to leave early and attack any intruders.

entries.name: Restoration Pod
entries: There are six pods in this chamber (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}").

This clean, organised chamber contains a glass and metal pod, a large pool filled with tadpoles, a wall pod and series of shelves. The burnished metal walls are engraved with enormous brains and tentacles.

entries.name: Shelves
entries: The shelves contain brain tissue samples preserved between sheets of glass. The brains belonged to gith, and contain important, preserved memories.

entries.name: Tadpole Pool
entries: The pool contains mind flayer tadpoles. Any creature that falls into a pool is beset by the creatures which could, at the Dm's discretion, initiate ceremorphosis.

entries.name: Storage Pod
entries: The pod contains a set of {@item dimensional shackles} used to prevent gith escaping during interviews.

entries.name: Restoration Pod
entries: There is a single pod in this chamber (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}").

entries.name: Engravings
entries: Characters who observe the wall engravings notice a repeated motif of four brains being placed into ornate jars, a clue to the abjuration brains.

entries.name: 87. Treasure Safe
entries: This area is protected by a Qualith door lock (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}") which is trapped.

entries.name: Mind Melter
entries: {@i Simple trap (level 17–20, deadly threat)}
A lethal dose of psionic force is released when a crystal in the door is broken, sapping the intellect of nearby creatures.

entries.name: Trigger
entries: Attempting to open the door triggers the trap.

entries.name: Effect
entries: The triggering creature must make a DC 20 Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the target's Intelligence score is reduced by {@dice 3d4}. The creature dies if this reduces its Intelligence to 0. Otherwise, the reduction lasts untli the creature benefits from {@spell greater restoration} or similar magic.

entries.name: Countermeasures
entries: A successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals a crystal embedded in the door's frame. A successful DC 20 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb} disables the crystal, but a check with a total of 10 or lower triggers the trap.
Gdy wchodzą postacie, przeczytaj lub sparafrazuj poniższe:
You enter a small chamber lined with shelves. Resting upon these are sundry items that appear immensely valuable, includign a platinum crown and a portrait of an elf.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The shelves contain several items of value:

items: A platinum crown of elvish design which incorporates moons and waves, encrusted with sapphires along the motifs (15,000 gp)
A necklace of black pearls with a ruby-eyed obsidian spider pendant (12,000 gp)
A model ship gilded with gold and silver filigree in a crystal bottle (8,000 gp)
A silken mantle that resembles a large spider web with gemstones embroidered in (2,5000 gp)
A portrait of a beautiful elven queen in royal regalia holding a moon-topped sceptre (characters might recognise the queen as Shava) (2,500 gp)

entries.name: Secret Pod
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher notice the frame of a pod on the far wall. A successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check opens the pod (see below).

entries.name: Canopic Jar
entries: Inside the pod is a canopic jar containing a spellcaster's brain concentrating on the {@spell globe of invulnerability} spell (see "{@area Abjuration Brains|abjuration brains|x}").
A metal cage built into the wall of this chamber contains three stunned-looking, green-skinned humanoids.

entries.name: Anti-travel Field
entries: This chamber is protected by a psionic aura that prevents teleportation of any kind. Casting {@spell dispel magic} (DC 15) removes the field.

entries.name: Cage
entries: The cages are barred and have Qualith door locks (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}"). The bars can be bent or broken with a successful DC 20 Strength check, allowing Large or smaller creatures to pass through.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: THree stunned {@creature githyanki warrior|mm|githyanki warriors} are trapped in the cage. One has an {@creature intellect devourer} in its skull, which the others do not know. If released, the devourer-inhabited githyanki tries to lure the characters and other githyanki into chambers occupied by mind flayers.

entries.name: Baldur's Gate
entries: If characters failed to rescue {@creature Ramazith Flamesinger|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) he is trapped here. His brain has beeen switched with an {@creature intellect devourer} (replcae the gith).

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: This floor providfes access to {@area 48|48} via a hole in the floor.

entries.name: 89. Gith Prison
entries: The DC to open this Qualith door lock (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}") is 30. When characters enter, read or paraphrase the following:
Beyond is a chamber with padded walls, ceiling, and floor. It glows with an oppressive red light, and a dull throbbing is audible within. Inside are two green-skinned humanoids.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The room contains a female {@creature githyanki knight} named Vairruth and a male {@creature githzerai zerth} named Muurg—Duskis' prisoners. The two hate each other and have been unable to put aside their cultural differences. They argue constantly, breaking out into violence at times.

entries.name: Antimagic Field
entries: The entire area is within an {@spell antimagic field}. A casting of {@spell dispel magic} (DC 20) removes the field.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: The characters have the opportunity to gain several levels throughout Ascarle. Examples include:

items: After an abjuration brain is destroyed
After a major NPC, such as Shava the Damned, Vestress, or Qualnus is defeated or converted to the characters' cause
After the characters overcome a complex trap
After one of the named mind flayers is killed
After characters kill Slarkrethel or Zellix'Phor

entries.name: Astral Retreat
entries: If you wish to continue the adventure beyond Ascarle, this section provides some opportunity to do so. Each of the mind flayers and Zellix'Phor itself have the ability to cast {@spell plane shift}. This spell can be used to evacuate the entire illithid colony from Ascarle to the Fractured Hand, a location on the Astral Plane. The Fractured Hand is an enormous stone hand, part of a dead god, floating through the silvery void that is the Astral Sea.
When characters arrive, read or paraphrase the following:

Stretching out before you is a colossal hand of fractured stone. Despite the scale, the detail of the grand sculpture is incredible. Vein-like ridges mark the surface beside wrinkled furrows. In the palm of the hand is a boulder coated with silver, bolted into which are domes of glass and star metal.

entries.name: Resting
entries: The reason the mind flayers flee to the Fractured Hand is to recoup and and present a unified front in defence of the characters' assault. If the characters take an hour to reach the Astral Plane, the illithids get a short rest. If the characters take 8 or more, they get a long rest.

entries.name: Elder Brain Lair
entries: The illithid outpost on the Fractured Hand is protected by the Lair Actions and Regional Effects of {@creature elder brain|vgm|Zellix'Phor}.

entries.name: Astral Plane
entries: The Astral Plane is an alien place of swirling lights and the petrified corpses of dead gods. Creatures on the Astral Plane don't age or suffer from hunger or thirst. A traveler in the Astral Plane can move by simply thinking about moving, but distance has little meaning in the endless plane. In combat, a creature's walking speed (in feet) is equal to 3 × its Intelligence score. The smarter a creature is, the easier it can control its movement by act of will.

If you want to further increase the peril of fighting the illithid in the Astral Plane you could have a {@table Psychic Wind} scour the surface of the Fractured Hand (see {@book chapter 2|dmg|2|Psychic Wind|0} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}), or have an {@creature astral dreadnought|mtf} attempt to consume the entire hand while the characters and illithid battle it out within.

entries.name: The Fractured Hand
entries: The Fractured Hand is roughly two miles long and one mile wide, its only major feature being the small illithid outpost built into a boulder which sits in its palm. The outpost uses the "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}", and is similar in decor and feel.

entries.name: Entrance
entries: The main entrance to the outpost is from the west—an open archway leading to Zellix'Phor's resting pool. The entrance is guarded by four {@creature githzerai zerth} thralls. If Zellix'Phor is in the chamber beyond, it can use its Lair Actions and Regional Effects to hinder the characters.

entries.name: Elder Brain Chambers
entries: The resting pool of Zellix'Phor has the same properties of that in {@area 70|70} of the Dungeons of Ascarle, though it is not protected by the same glass dome. The doors to enter are Qualith door locks (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}") but the DC to open them by any means is 30. Any remaining mind flayers that made it to the Astral Plane defend Zellix'Phor here.

entries.name: Brain Library
entries: North of the elder brain chamber is a brain library which contains the brains of notable gith leaders.

entries.name: Research Chamber
entries: To the south of the elder brain chamber is a cavern filled with laboratory equipment which the mind flayers use in their biological and psionic research. The facilities are guarded by four {@filter mutants|bestiary|source=CallfromtheDeep|search=mutant} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}).

entries.name: Tower & Dungeon
entries: Neither the tower nor dungeon lead anywhere in particular unless the DM needs them to. While the dungeon has a regular spiral stair, the tower can onyl be accessed by flying creatures.

data.name: Conclusion
entries: Zellix'Phor is an elder brain focussed on domination, who believes itself undefeatable. The characters will hopefully be able to prove the elder brain wrong. By killing Zellix'Phor, or at the least routing it to the Astral Plane, the characters have saved Faerûn from an invasion of the most malicious kind. Without Zellix'Phor, any mind flayers left on the Material Plane are left directionless and lost, perhaps retreating into the Underdark, where others of their kind hide away, and joining other colonies or going rogue.

Whether the characters decide to kill Slarkrethel the kraken will have a potentially enormous effect across the Island Kingdoms and the Sword Coast, as members of the Kraken Society suddenly find themselves without guidance or leadership, the folk of Purple Rocks are left without their cultural cornerstone, and Umberlee is deprived of her chosen avatar on the Material Plane. What happens to these groups is up to the DM, but Slarkrethel's followers are unlikely to be able to reintegrate into society once their psychic master is destroyed. The characters might even face the wrath of {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag} in full, as the very oceans turn against them.

The future of the characters is, of course, up to them. Their heroic victory over the astral invaders should spread quickly thorughout Faerûn, and the folk of the Realms laud them as heroes wherever they find themselves next.

data.name: Appendix A: Random Encounters
entries: {@note Due to the limitations of 5etools' engine, the following table is not interactive. However, you can use this {@dice d100} to save some typing, or one of the environment-specific tables in the column headings.}

rows: 39-{@footnote 45|This value is duplicated in the source.}
{@footnote 45|This value is duplicated in the source.}-46
{@adventure NPC in the water|CallfromtheDeep|11|NPC in the water|0}

entries: Random encounters can occur whilst the characters are exploring the Sword Coast or the Island Kingdoms, either on land, by sea, or underwater. Such encounters can add to the mystery of the adventure, give the players a sense that their characters are immersed in a real world, and provide narrative setbacks or advantages. Random encounters are best used whenever there's a lull in the game session or when your players seem restless. No more than one or two per session is recommended since overusing random encounters can bog down the adventure and cause the players to lose track of the story.

While the characters are travelling through Faerûn, roll a {@dice d20} twice per day of game time, checking for encounters each morning or afternoon, and evening or night. An encounter occurs on a roll of 14 or higher. Roll {@dice d100|percentile dice} and check the {@table Random Encounters|CallfromtheDeep} table for the terrain appropriate to where the characters are. After determining what the characters encounter, you can use the information presented in this appendix to bring the encounter to life.

If your players tire of random encounters, make such encounters less common by having them occur on a roll of 18 or higher, or only 20. You can let the players narrate their way through avoiding easy encounters, or you can increase the difficulty of easy encounters to keep them exciting. One way to make an encounter more challenging is to have it trigger a second random encounter. For example, a fight with pirates in a coastal cove might attract a {@creature manticore} which lairs nearby. You can also shorten encounters by having monsters flee when they lose most of their hit points.

Random encounters aren't tailored to characters of a particular level. If the characters encounter hostile creatures beyond their ability to defeat, give them opportunities to run, hide, negotiate, or otherwise avoid certain death.

Remember that random encounters affect both the characters and any non-player characters they are travelling with. The most common example of this are members of a ship's crew. If the characters have a random encounter with {@creature harpy|mm|harpies}, the crew are just as likely to be {@condition charmed} by the {@creature harpy|mm|harpies} and flown off to their lair as the characters are.

entries.name: Aldani
entries: The characters are shadowed by {@dice 1d4} {@creature aldani (lobsterfolk)|Toa|aldani} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}), which are noticed by any character with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 12 or higher. The aldani don't communicate with others unless they must, and they won't fight unless the characters refuse to take a bribe to leave the area.
The aldani aid the characters only if they're offered something of great value in return—for example, an offer to drive off a pack of predatory sahuagin encroaching on their territory.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The aldani try to bribe the characters to leave the area with coral trinkets worth 50 gp each per character. If the characters refuse, the aldani might attack.

entries.name: Ankheg
entries: A group of {@dice 1d3} {@creature ankheg|mm|ankhegs} bursts up from beneath the ground to ambush the characters. Any character without {@sense tremorsense|MM} is surprised by the attack. Ankhegs prefer Small creatures, which they grab with their mandibles and drag back underground to consume.
Alternatively, the characters could encounter the ankhegs destroying a field of sheep, or chasing after a pair of fleeing halflings.

entries.name: Bandits
entries: A marauding gang of bandits confronts the party. The gang consists of a {@creature bandit captain} and {@dice 3d6 + 2} {@creature bandit|mm|bandits}, all wearing cloaks and mounted on {@creature riding horse|mm|riding horses}. There is a {@chance 25} chance that the bandits attack without provocation. Otherwise, the captain promises not to attack in exchange for a toll (no less than 100 gp worth of treasure). If the characters pay up, the captain bids them a safe journey before departing peacefully.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each bandit carries a pouch containing {@dice 1d10} gp. The bandit captain's pouch holds {@dice 2d10} gp and {@dice 1d6} gems worth 100 gp each.

entries.name: Barbarians
entries: The characters encounter a group of {@dice 2d6 + 2} {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors}, led by a {@creature berserker}. If the encounter occurs during the day, the barbarians are prowling the countryside while hunting wild game; if the encounter occurs at night, they are camped.

entries.name: The North
entries: If this encounter occurs in The North, the characters encounter an Uthgardt Barbarian tribe, led by an {@creature Uthgardt shaman|SKT} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) with an additional {@creature berserker} bodyguard.

entries.name: Sea or Coast
entries: If the encounter occurs at sea or on the coast, the characters encounter {@dice 1d3} {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep|longships}, each with ten {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers} and thirty {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors} aboard. One of the {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers} serves as the captain. These hostile, bloodthirsty Northfolk raiders hail from Gundarlun, the Korinn Archipelago, Tuern, or the Whalebones. The {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep|longships} have a speed of 3 miles per hour. If the vessel the characters are in moves at least as fast, the characters can flee from the barbarians and avoid an altercation.

entries.name: Blood Hawks
entries: A vicious kettle of {@dice 2d4+2} {@creature blood hawk|mm|blood hawks} attacks the party from above. These crimson raptors are fearless and attack large creatures without second thought. The hawks target already injured characters or those who look weaker than the rest of the party.

entries.name: Coelenites
entries: The characters are attacked by {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) who try and pull them down into the water and drown them. The {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} try to avoid leaving the ocean if possible but foray onto the shore or climb aboard boats to pursue their prey.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are 4th level or higher, replace one of the {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} with a {@creature coelenite mass mind|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). The {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} telepathically threaten the characters with drowning unless they provide a tribute of food. The {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} can be appeased with food (four day's supply per coelenite in the group). Otherwise, they attack.

entries.name: Dolphins
entries: The characters spot a pod of {@dice 3d4} {@creature dolphin|vgm|dolphins} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). If the characters are above the surface of the water, they notice the beautiful creatures leaping between the waves. They are naturally inquisitive and might come within 10 feet of the boat to take a look.

A {@creature dolphin|vgm} that is successfully {@condition grappled}, caught in a {@item net|phb}, or otherwise prevented from escaping can be trained as a mount by a character with proficiency in {@skill Animal Handling} who spends a few hours a day working with the mammal. At the end of 1 week, the character makes a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. On a success, the dolphin becomes a willing mount for any humanoid.

entries.name: Druid
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature druid} who might be a member of the Emerald Enclave or simply devoted to protecting a certain area of wilderness. Most druids are happy to give guidance on traversing their lands, provided the characters are respectful of the environment on their travels. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the druid is accompanied by an animal companion. Two sample druids are presented below, but you can create others.

Jillian Leafgather (NG female lightfoot halfling) is a member of the Emerald Enclave accompanied by her massive, relentlessly slobbering {@creature mastiff}, Bungo. Jillian despises animal cruelty, and even considers insulting animals verbally to be intolerable. She knows a few shortcuts around the Sword Mountains and Neverwinter Wood, which she happily shares with characters in need. The shortcuts allow characters to move at a fast pace without any penalties.

Orsik Oakenheim (CE male mountain dwarf) is wild and rugged. He believes that the wilds should overtake civilisation, and all folk should go back to living as nomadic tribes in the wilderness. He wears a huge fur coat and trapper hat which conceals eight {@creature twig blight|mm|twig blights}. Orsik happily converses with characters, but if he deems them too involved with society, he tries to orchestrate their deaths. This can be achieved by sending characters into dangerous terrain such as scree slopes, {@trap quicksand} or predator territory.
